{"source": "Eval/Chemical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "The chemical engineering profession is rapidly changing and knowledge of specialty areas has become essential in the real world. Technical elective courses are intended to provide an opportunity to introduce students to a specialty area in science and engineering and help them to expand their knowledge and expertise in new areas of chemical engineering. Although it is recommended that a minimum of eight credit hours be focused in one subject area, students are encouraged to focus most or all of the 20 credit hours of electives in a particular subject area. In many cases students can use their electives to take a package of courses toward an area minor such as, biochemical engineering, applied biology, biomedical engineering, chemistry, environmental engineering, toward a certificate in semiconductor materials and devices, or toward an area of concentration (see below).", "lemma": "chemical engineering profession be rapidly change knowledge specialty area have become essential real world. Technical elective course be intend provide opportunity introduce student specialty area science engineering help expand knowledge expertise new area chemical engineering. be recommend minimum credit hour be focus subject area, student be encourage focus most credit hour elective particular subject area. many case student use elective take package course area minor such as, biochemical engineering, apply biology, biomedical engineering, chemistry, environmental engineering, certificate semiconductor material devices, area concentration (see below)."}
{"source": "Eval/Chemical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "Undergraduate students have the opportunity to work on a research project under the guidance of one of the departmental faculty members. Students who are interested in learning about research should talk to members of the faculty to define a project of mutual interest and then enroll in CHE499, Directed Research. Credit hours of CHE499 can count toward an approved elective.\n\nMinor in Chemical Engineering\n\nThe minor in chemical engineering is designed to introduce principles of chemical engineering to students majoring in other disciplines. Participation in this minor will help students to understand chemical engineering aspects of industrial processes and enter a graduate program in chemical engineering if they desire.\n\nStudents who complete the minor in chemical engineering during their sophomore and junior years open the possibility of taking some chemical engineering electives during their senior years.\n\nThe minor in chemical engineering has the following requirements:", "lemma": "Undergraduate student have opportunity work research project guidance departmental faculty members. {"source": "Eval/Computer%20Engineering.txt", "text": "Computer Engineering\n\nComputer Engineers (CPE) are electrical engineers that have additional training in the areas of software design and hardware-software integration. Common CPE tasks include writing embedded software for real-time microcontrollers, designing VLSI chips, working with analog sensors, designing mixed signal circuit boards, and designing operating systems. Computer engineers are also well-suited for research in the field of robotics, which relies on using computers together with other electrical systems. Below is a recommended plan of study for CPE.\n\nCPE program educational objectives\n\nComputer Engineering graduates shall:\n\nPractice excellence in their profession using a systems approach encompassing technological, economic, ethical, environmental, social, and human issues within a changing global environment;\n\nFunction independently and in leadership positions within multidisciplinary teams;", "lemma": "Computer Engineering Computer Engineers (CPE) be electrical engineer have additional training area software design hardware-software integration. Common CPE task include write embed software real-time microcontrollers, design VLSI chips, work analog sensors, design mixed signal circuit boards, design operate systems. Computer engineer be also well-suited research field robotics, rely use computer together other electrical systems. Below be recommended plan study CPE. CPE program educational objective Computer Engineering graduate shall: Practice excellence profession use system approach encompass technological, economic, ethical, environmental, social, human issue change global environment; Function independently leadership position multidisciplinary teams;"}
{"source": "Eval/Computer%20Engineering.txt", "text": "Function independently and in leadership positions within multidisciplinary teams;\n\nContinue life-long learning by acquiring new knowledge, mastering emerging technologies, and using\u00a0 appropriate tools and methods;\n\nAdapt and independently extend their learning to excel in fields about which they are passionate;\n\nStrengthen teams and communities through collaboration, effective communication, public service, and leadership.\n\nCPE Student Learning Outcomes\n\nAt the time of graduation, students will have demonstrated:\n\nan ability to identify, formulate, and solve complex engineering problems by applying principles of engineering, science, and mathematics\n\nan ability to apply engineering design to produce solutions that meet specified needs with consideration of public health, safety, and welfare, as well as global, cultural, social, environmental, and economic factors\n\nan ability to communicate effectively with a range of audiences", "lemma": "Function independently leadership position multidisciplinary teams; Continue life-long learning acquire new knowledge, master emerge technologies, use appropriate tool methods; Adapt independently extend learning excel field be passionate; Strengthen team community collaboration, effective communication, public service, leadership. {"source": "Eval/Student-Handbook14.txt", "text": "5. In all instances, the instructor shall submit a brief written report of the case \nand any action taken to the Dean of Students, the Head of department, and the student. In case a penalty course grade (F, D, or D+) has been assigned, a copy of the report shall also be submitted to the Registrar. These reports \nwill be kept on file until the student graduates, at which time the records will \nbe destroyed. If the case is successfully appealed, the records will be expunged unless the student requests that they be retained. For example, they may be retained in an instance where the course grade has been \nlowered by the instructor but the Committee subsequently exonerated the \nstudent. {"source": "Eval/International%20Computer%20Science.txt", "text": "International Computer Science\n\nThe International Computer Science curriculum prepares students for careers in all areas of the computer industry as well as for graduate studies in computer science and computer related fields. Students have also found a computer science major to be excellent preparation for careers in law, medicine, business administration, industrial engineering, biomedical engineering, and other technical and non-technical fields.\n\nComputer science is a rapidly changing discipline. The lifetime of a particular computer system or software package can be very short. The international computer science curriculum is designed to prepare students for multiple careers in a rapidly changing, global environment. The program\u2019s courses emphasize fundamental concepts and techniques that will last longer than present technology.", "lemma": "International Computer Science International Computer Science curriculum prepare student career area computer industry as well graduate study computer science computer relate fields. Students have also find computer science major be excellent preparation career law, medicine, business administration, industrial engineering, biomedical engineering, other technical non-technical fields. Computer science be rapidly change discipline. lifetime particular computer system software package be very short. international computer science curriculum be design prepare student multiple career rapidly changing, global environment. program\u2019s course emphasize fundamental concept technique last long present technology."}
{"source": "Eval/International%20Computer%20Science.txt", "text": "International computer science majors complete a core of basic computer science courses that includes the study of algorithms, data structures, database concepts, computer systems, computer architecture, programming languages, operating systems, and software engineering. Advanced courses in theory of computation, computer networks, distributed systems, security, and real time systems add depth to the degree program. A three-term senior thesis provides students the opportunity to research in depth an area of computer science that is of interest to them under the mentorship of a faculty member. Majors also complete important courses in closely related fields, e.g., discrete mathematics and probability and statistics, as well as study a foreign language. The major requires students to study all aspects of the science of computing, including hardware, software, and theory.", "lemma": "International computer science major complete core basic computer science course include study algorithms, data structures, database concepts, computer systems, computer architecture, program languages, operate systems, software engineering. Advanced course theory computation, computer networks, distribute systems, security, real time system add depth degree program. three-term senior thesis provide student opportunity research depth area computer science be interest mentorship faculty member. Majors also complete important course closely related fields, e.g., discrete mathematics probability statistics, as well study foreign language. major require student study aspect science computing, include hardware, software, theory."}
{"source": "Eval/International%20Computer%20Science.txt", "text": "Five free electives allow students to tailor their undergraduate education to their specific goals and pursue topics of interest to them. Students may choose to do advanced elective work in computer science and software engineering and/or in the humanities and social sciences, and/or pursue a minor or double major in another discipline.\n\nProgramming assignments and large projects are part of most computer science courses. These assignments familiarize students with the wide variety of tasks performed by software professionals. Programming assignments include system specification, system feasibility studies, system design, system maintenance studies, and user interface design in addition to system implementation (i.e., coding), testing (verification and validation), and documentation. Projects include both individual and team activities and require appropriate written and oral presentations.", "lemma": "free elective allow student tailor undergraduate education specific goal pursue topic interest them. Students choose do advanced elective work computer science software engineering and/or humanity social sciences, and/or pursue minor double major discipline. Programming assignment large project be part most computer science courses. assignment familiarize student wide variety task perform software professionals. Programming assignment include system specification, system feasibility studies, system design, system maintenance studies, user interface design addition system implementation (i.e., coding), test (verification validation), documentation. Projects include individual team activity require appropriate write oral presentations."}
{"source": "Eval/International%20Computer%20Science.txt", "text": "The department has its own local area network. This network is connected to the campus-wide network and the Internet. Department laboratories provide docking stations and large screen monitors for students to attach their laptops to. International computer science majors have unlimited access to the department\u2019s laboratories.\n\nThe department has active programming teams that compete in the ACM Programming Contest and the Collegiate Cyber Defense Competition. The national computer science honor society, Upsilon Pi Epsilon, has chartered its Indiana Alpha Chapter at Rose-Hulman; it sponsors several seminars throughout the year.\n\nInternational Computer Science Program Educational Objectives", "lemma": "department have own local area network. network be connect campus-wide network Internet. Department laboratories provide dock station large screen monitor student attach laptop to. International computer science major have unlimited access department\u2019s laboratories. department have active program team compete ACM Programming Contest Collegiate Cyber Defense Competition. national computer science honor society, Upsilon Pi Epsilon, have charter Indiana Alpha Chapter Rose-Hulman; sponsor several seminar year. International Computer Science Program Educational Objectives"}
{"source": "Eval/International%20Computer%20Science.txt", "text": "International Computer Science Program Educational Objectives\n\nGraduates from the international computer science program will be prepared for many types of careers in the field of computing and prepared for graduate study in computer science and in closely related disciplines. In the early phases of their careers, we expect Rose-Hulman international computer science graduates to be:\n\nComputing professionals in a variety of organizations, including ones doing traditional software development, technological innovation, and cross-disciplinary work\n\nBusiness and technological leaders within existing organizations\n\nEntrepreneurial leaders\n\nRecognized by their peers and superiors for their communication, teamwork, and leadership skills\n\nActively involved in social and professional service locally, nationally, and globally\n\nGraduate students and researchers\n\nLeaders in government and law as government employees, policy makers, governmental advisors, and legal professionals\n\nInternational Computer Science Student Outcomes", "lemma": "International Computer Science Program Educational Objectives Graduates international computer science program be prepare many type career field compute prepared graduate study computer science closely related disciplines. early phase careers, expect Rose-Hulman international computer science graduate be: Computing professional variety organizations, include one do traditional software development, technological innovation, cross-disciplinary work Business technological leader exist organization Entrepreneurial leader Recognized peer superior communication, teamwork, leadership skill Actively involve social professional service locally, nationally, globally Graduate student researcher Leaders government law government employees, policy makers, governmental advisors, legal professional International Computer Science Student Outcomes"}
{"source": "Eval/International%20Computer%20Science.txt", "text": "International Computer Science Student Outcomes\n\nBy the time students graduate with an international computer science degree from Rose-Hulman, they will be able to:\n\nEffectively apply a variety of computing resources, programming languages, programming paradigms, operating systems, networks, and software development tools\n\nAnticipate complexities and problems involved in the development of large computing systems\n\nAnalyze requirements, design computing systems that satisfy those requirements, and implement that system\n\nAnalyze problems and design solutions using ideas of problem complexity, models of computation, decidability, and scalability\n\nAnalyze algorithms in terms of correctness, as well as time and space efficiency\n\nEvaluate and discuss the legal, social, and ethical aspects of significant events that arise in the field of computing both domestically and internationally", "lemma": "International Computer Science Student Outcomes time student graduate international computer science degree Rose-Hulman, be able to: Effectively apply variety compute resources, program languages, program paradigms, operate systems, networks, software development tool Anticipate complexity problem involve development large compute system Analyze requirements, design compute system satisfy requirements, implement system Analyze problem design solution use idea problem complexity, model computation, decidability, scalability Analyze algorithm term correctness, as well time space efficiency Evaluate discuss legal, social, ethical aspect significant event arise field compute domestically internationally"}

No more than four credits may be at the 200 level, and none of the credits may be from CSSE 372, 373, 375, 376, and 477. The students academic advisor must approve the courses to satisfy this requirement. {"source": "Eval/Mechanical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "Mechanical Engineering\n\nMechanical engineering is a broad field of endeavor with opportunities in many areas of industry: production and manufacturing; aeronautics and aerospace; robotics and automation; conventional and renewable energy; automotive and transportation; and many others. Additional opportunities for mechanical engineers include careers in government, education, and private consulting. The mechanical engineering curriculum is designed to prepare students for this wide range of options by providing them with a strong foundation in the fundamental principles of science and engineering to tackle the complex technological problems of today and adapt for the challenges of tomorrow.", "lemma": "Mechanical Engineering Mechanical engineering be broad field endeavor opportunity many area industry: production manufacturing; aeronautics aerospace; robotics automation; conventional renewable energy; automotive transportation; many others. Additional opportunity mechanical engineer include career government, education, private consulting. mechanical engineering curriculum be design prepare student wide range option provide strong foundation fundamental principle science engineering tackle complex technological problem today adapt challenge tomorrow."}
{"source": "Eval/Mechanical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "The required courses of the undergraduate mechanical engineering curriculum provide the basic mathematical and scientific fundamentals underlying the practice of mechanical engineering. Technical, free, and math/science elective courses allow the student flexibility in adapting the program to their interests in pursuit of their specific career goals. Electives in the humanities, social sciences, and the arts help to foster the links between society and engineering so that the mechanical engineering graduate is aware of the roles of engineering and science in solving complex technological and social problems as well as of the impacts of social and environmental factors on engineering activities such as design. For those undergraduates who choose to continue their education at Rose-Hulman, graduate work leading to a Master of Science in Mechanical Engineering or a Master of Engineering in Mechanical Engineering is offered by the department.", "lemma": "required course undergraduate mechanical engineering curriculum provide basic mathematical scientific fundamental underlie practice mechanical engineering. Technical, free, math/science elective course allow student flexibility adapt program interest pursuit specific career goals. Electives humanities, social sciences, art help foster link society engineering so mechanical engineering graduate be aware role engineering science solve complex technological social problem as well impact social environmental factor engineering activity such design. undergraduate choose continue education Rose-Hulman, graduate work lead Master Science Mechanical Engineering Master Engineering Mechanical Engineering be offer department."}
{"source": "Eval/Mechanical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "Mission: To provide the curriculum, the educational environment, and the individual support necessary to graduate mechanical engineers who are technically competent, effective in practice, creative, ethical, and mindful of their responsibility to society.\n\nVision:\u00a0To graduate the best baccalaureate mechanical engineers.\n\nMechanical Engineering Program Educational Objectives and Student Outcomes\n\nProgram Educational Objectives", "lemma": "Mission: provide curriculum, educational environment, individual support necessary graduate mechanical engineer be technically competent, effective practice, creative, ethical, mindful responsibility society. Vision: graduate best baccalaureate mechanical engineers. Mechanical Engineering Program Educational Objectives Student Outcomes Program Educational Objectives"}
{"source": "Eval/Mechanical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "Mechanical Engineering Program Educational Objectives and Student Outcomes\n\nProgram Educational Objectives\n\nThe mechanical engineering curriculum aims to prepare students for productive careers in industry, government, education, and private consulting, as well as for graduate study. By providing a strong foundation in the fundamental principles of science and engineering and by illuminating the links between society and engineering, the curriculum enables students to apply what they have learned and to teach themselves new skills to address complex technological problems within the social and environmental context of our world. Thus, within a few years of graduation, we expect our graduates to attain the following educational objectives, which are based on the needs of our constituencies:\n\nOur alumni will be successful in their careers.\n\nOur alumni set and meet their own goals for career fulfillment.\n\nOur alumni will continue professional development.", "lemma": "Mechanical Engineering Program Educational Objectives Student Outcomes Program Educational Objectives mechanical engineering curriculum aim prepare student productive career industry, government, education, private consulting, as well graduate study. provide strong foundation fundamental principle science engineering illuminate link society engineering, curriculum enable student apply have learn teach new skill address complex technological problem social environmental context world. Thus, few year graduation, expect graduate attain following educational objectives, be base need constituencies: alumnus be successful careers. alumnus set meet own goal career fulfillment. alumnus continue professional development."}
{"source": "Eval/Mechanical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "Our alumni will continue professional development.\n\nOur alumni will be cognizant of the international dimensions of their profession.\n\nStudent Outcomes\n\nStudent outcomes describe what students are expected to know and be able to do by the time of graduation. These relate to the skills, knowledge, and behaviors that students acquire as they progress through the program. We expect our graduates to have the ability to:\n\nIdentify, formulate, and solve complex engineering problems by applying principles of engineering, science, and mathematics.\n\nApply engineering design to produce solutions that meet specified needs with consideration of public health, safety, and welfare, as well as global, cultural, social, environmental, and economic factors.\n\nCommunicate effectively with a range of audiences.", "lemma": "alumnus continue professional development. alumnus be cognizant international dimension profession. Student Outcomes Student outcomes describe student be expect know be able do time graduation. relate skills, knowledge, behavior student acquire progress program. expect graduate have ability to: Identify, formulate, solve complex engineering problem apply principle engineering, science, mathematics. Apply engineering design produce solution meet specified need consideration public health, safety, welfare, as well global, cultural, social, environmental, economic factors. Communicate effectively range audiences."}
{"source": "Eval/Mechanical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "Communicate effectively with a range of audiences.\n\nRecognize ethical and professional responsibilities in engineering situations and make informed judgments, which must consider the impact of engineering solutions in global, economic, environmental, and societal contexts.\n\nFunction effectively on a team whose members together provide leadership, create a collaborative and inclusive environment, establish goals, plan tasks, and meet objectives.\n\nDevelop and conduct appropriate experimentation, analyze and interpret data, and use engineering judgment to draw conclusion.\n\nAcquire and apply new knowledge as needed, using appropriate learning strategies.\n\nThe mechanical engineering program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org, under the commission\u2019s General Criteria and Program Criteria for Mechanical and Similarly Named Engineering Programs.\n\nSummary of degree requirements", "lemma": "Communicate effectively range audiences. {"source": "Eval/Mechanical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "Summary of degree requirements\n\nThe freshman year of the mechanical engineering program includes courses in mathematics and foundational sciences, as well as introductory courses in engineering and design. Foundational sciences include physics, biology, and chemistry.\u00a0The sophomore year features courses in mathematics, foundational sciences, and the engineering sciences. The final two years of the program stress the design and analysis of systems, machines and their components, and the transfer and transformation of energy. In addition to the required mathematics, science, and engineering courses, the program includes required writing and communication courses and an array of technical electives and free electives, a math/science elective, and elective courses in the humanities, social sciences, and the arts (HSSA). The requirements for an undergraduate degree in mechanical engineering are summarized in the following table:", "lemma": "Summary degree requirement freshman year mechanical engineering program include course mathematics foundational sciences, as well introductory course engineering design. Foundational science include physics, biology, chemistry. sophomore year feature course mathematics, foundational sciences, engineering sciences. final year program stress design analysis systems, machine components, transfer transformation energy. addition required mathematics, science, engineering courses, program include require writing communication course array technical elective free electives, math/science elective, elective course humanities, social sciences, art (HSSA). requirement undergraduate degree mechanical engineering be summarize following table:"}

Identify, formulate, solve problem area manufacturing."}

{"source": "Eval/Mechanical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "Areas of Concentration\n\nStudents who complete recommended courses in an area of concentration may receive, upon request, a letter from the Department Head attesting to the fact that the student has completed the requirements in the selected area of concentration in the Mechanical Engineering Department. With proper planning, students should be able to take these course offerings without overload. Students may\u00a0add special topics courses or new courses not yet listed in the catalog to the list of acceptable courses for a concentration with written permission from the mechanical engineering department head.\n\nAutomotive Area of Concentration", "lemma": "Areas Concentration Students complete recommend course area concentration receive, request, letter Department Head attest fact student have complete requirement selected area concentration Mechanical Engineering Department. proper planning, student be able take course offering overload. {"source": "Eval/Mechanical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "Automotive Area of Concentration\n\nAutomotive Engineering is a very broad field covering many topics including system modeling, combustion, electrification, autonomous driving, materials, and virtual design. To help prepare for a career in this field, the Automotive Concentration is offered. One required and four elective courses are necessary, allowing students to gain either breadth or depth according to their interests.\n\nRequired Course:\n\nME 359 Vehicle System Modeling\n\nElective Courses (choose any four):\n\nCSSE 461 Computer Vision\n\nCSSE 463 Image Recognition\n\nEM 402 Three Dimensional Dynamics\n\nEM 403 Advanced Mechanics of Materials\n\nMA 416 Deep Learning\n\nME 401 Foundations of Fluid Mechanics\n\nME 406 Control Systems\n\nME 408 Renewable Energy\n\nME 410 Internal Combustion Engines\n\nME 422 Finite Elements for Engineering Applications", "lemma": "Automotive Area Concentration Automotive Engineering be very broad field cover many topic include system modeling, combustion, electrification, autonomous driving, materials, virtual design. help prepare career field, Automotive Concentration be offered. require elective course be necessary, allow student gain breadth depth accord interests. {"source": "Eval/Mechanical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "**28 credit hours in electives composed of 16 credit hours in technical electives, 8 credit hours in free electives, and 4 credit hours of a math elective or a science elective.\u00a0 A technical elective is any course (at the 200 level or above) in biomathematics, chemistry, computer science, engineering, engineering management, geology, mathematics, or physics that is not cross-listed with HSSA or similar in content to a required course.\u00a0 A\u00a0math elective is at the 200-level or higher and has an MA or BMTH prefix.\u00a0 A\u00a0science elective is any course in biology, chemistry, geology, or physics except those courses that are cross-listed with an engineering course.", "lemma": "**28 credit hour elective compose credit hour technical electives, credit hour free electives, credit hour math elective science elective. technical elective be course (at level above) biomathematics, chemistry, computer science, engineering, engineering management, geology, mathematics, physic be not cross-listed HSSA similar content required course. A math elective be 200-level high have MA BMTH prefix. A science elective be course biology, chemistry, geology, physic course be cross-listed engineering course."}

The Faculty may substitute another penalty for suspension.  \n4. The Faculty may remand the case to the Institute Rules and Discipline Committee for re -sentencing (i.e., specifying that a penalty other than \nsuspension be assigned).  \n5. Individual users are expected to ensure that their activity does not preempt or hinder another user's activity. {"source": "Eval/ROTC-Army.txt", "text": "ROTC: Army\n\nThe completion of the Army ROTC program leads to a commission as a Second Lieutenant in the Active Army, Army Reserve or Army National Guard. Students completing the program receive their commissions upon graduation and serve a specified period of active duty ranging from three months to four years, depending upon the student\u2019s choice of commissioning program and Army requirements.\n\nCURRICULUM", "lemma": "ROTC: Army completion Army ROTC program lead commission Second Lieutenant Active Army, Army Reserve Army National Guard. {"source": "Eval/ROTC-Army.txt", "text": "CURRICULUM\n\nThe ROTC program specializes in teaching leadership and management skills required by the military and sought by civilian employers. ROTC cadets learn how to motivate co-workers and how to plan, organize and implement large projects and tasks. They also learn skills in demand in civilian businesses, such as teamwork, tact problem solving, decision making, and effective communication. The program includes the Basic Course for freshmen and sophomores and the Advanced Course for juniors and seniors. Students incur active duty and reserve commitments only upon enrollment in the Advanced Course or through the ROTC scholarship program and successful completion of the curriculum.\n\nStudents who miss out on the basic ROTC Freshman and Sophomore curriculum can attend a four-week (LTC) leadership training course at Fort Knox, KY., during the summer between their sophomore and junior years.", "lemma": "CURRICULUM ROTC program specializes teach leadership management skill require military seek civilian employers. ROTC cadet learn motivate co-worker plan, organize implement large project tasks. also learn skill demand civilian businesses, such teamwork, tact problem solving, decision making, effective communication. program include Basic Course freshman sophomore Advanced Course junior seniors. Students incur active duty reserve commitment only enrollment Advanced Course ROTC scholarship program successful completion curriculum. Students miss out basic ROTC Freshman Sophomore curriculum attend four-week (LTC) leadership training course Fort Knox, KY., summer sophomore junior years."}
{"source": "Eval/ROTC-Army.txt", "text": "In the Advanced Course, students must complete 18 credit hours of Military Science and the 5-week ROTC Leadership Development and Assessment Course (MS 304) at Fort Lewis, WA. Qualified students may also participate in Army Airborne, Air Assault, Northern Warfare, or Mountain Warfare training.\n\nVeterans and students who received ROTC training in high school should contact the Department concerning possible constructive credit for part or all of the Basic Course. Graduate students, transfer students and students who expect to complete degree requirements in less than four years should contact the Department concerning an accelerated program if they desire to obtain a commission. Other programs are available for selected students to complete the program in 2 years or less.\n\nAllowances", "lemma": "Advanced Course, student complete credit hour Military Science 5-week ROTC Leadership Development Assessment Course (MS Fort Lewis, WA. {"source": "Eval/ROTC-Army.txt", "text": "Allowances\n\nUniforms are furnished, when appropriate, to all students without charge. {"source": "Eval/ROTC-Army.txt", "text": "Scholarships\n\nROTC awards Full-Tuition scholarships plus free Room/Board per year, providing money for tuition and educational fees. Scholarships are awarded strictly on merit, although the Institute provides an additional financial incentive. Scholarship winners also receive a designated textbook allowance of $900 per year and a tax-free stipend allowance from $300-500 per month for up to 10 months for each year the scholarship is in effect. Four-year scholarships are open to high school graduates prior to entering Army ROTC as freshmen. The three and two year scholarships are available to students enrolled in ROTC at Rose-Hulman. Full details on the scholarship program may be obtained by contacting the ROTC office at 1 (800)-248-7448, extension 8348 or 8236, or by visiting the Army ROTC home page at", "lemma": "Scholarships ROTC award Full-Tuition scholarship free Room/Board year, provide money tuition educational fees. {"source": "Eval/Engineering%20Design.txt", "text": "Engineering Design\n\nA Bachelor of Science in Engineering Design\n\nAn engineering design degree opens the door to various positions in industry and graduate school. Your experience with client-focused design, prototyping, and professional skills will allow you to contribute to companies in any phase of the design process: identification of stakeholder needs, concept generation, feasibility studies, risk analysis, detail design, manufacturing, testing, validation, maintenance, and product lifecycle analysis.\n\nFacilities and Resources\n\nHands-on learning and prototyping is a key component of engineering design.\u00a0 Engineering design students use prototyping technology in design studios developed to encourage creativity and communication with all stakeholders. {"source": "Eval/Engineering%20Design.txt", "text": "Engineering Design\n\nEngineering design is a human-centered endeavor that grew out of investigations of creativity.\u00a0 While design is an integral part of all engineering fields, design methodology gained more attention during the 1980s as global competition demanded higher quality design and system complexity increased. The role of the designer is to create a system, process, product, or service based on stakeholder needs while considering social, environmental, economic, and safety requirements. The designer must have both a mindset and skillset for improving the impact of design on society. The mindset requires the vision and drive necessary to create value. The skillset includes the tools and techniques critical to realize the design.", "lemma": "Engineering Design Engineering design be human-centered endeavor grow investigation creativity. design be integral part engineering fields, design methodology gain more attention global competition demand high quality design system complexity increased. role designer be create system, process, product, service base stakeholder need consider social, environmental, economic, safety requirements. designer have mindset skillset improve impact design mindset require vision drive necessary create skillset include tool technique critical realize design."}
{"source": "Eval/Engineering%20Design.txt", "text": "The Engineering Design major prepares students by giving them repeated, intensive design experiences with real clients. From the first quarter to the senior year, students participate in authentic design experiences and practice professional skills. The first year gives students a broad understanding of modeling systems across disciplines and repeated practice in prototyping solutions for clients. Students select a concentration and prepare for their practicum as they continue deeper in the design process. Second year students also learn the process of on-boarding into existing projects as they work with seniors one quarter and freshmen another. Transitioning to the third year, students participate in two 20-week practicums. Students are required to delve into the design process. In the junior year, the curriculum is structured to allow study-work abroad and/ or cooperative work experiences. In their senior year, students complete their concentrations and participate in a", "lemma": "Engineering Design major prepares student give repeated, intensive design experience real clients. first quarter senior year, student participate authentic design experience practice professional skills. first year give student broad understanding model system discipline repeated practice prototyping solution clients. {"source": "Eval/Engineering%20Design.txt", "text": "Not include any named required courses\n\nPracticum Courses:\n\nAll engineering design students must take 16 hours of practicum courses.\u00a0\u00a0Enrollment in a practicum course requires professional employment such as an internship or co-op. Professional employment must average a minimum of 25 hours per week of work and have a duration of\u00a0at least eight weeks. Professional employment must include some aspects of the design process\u00a0such as commercialization, conceptual design, manufacturing, modeling, process improvement, product\u00a0design, product improvement, quality methods, testing, or design validation.\u00a0 Practicum courses are generally 300-level courses with the term \u201cPracticum\u201d in the catalog description.\n\nPlan of Study\n\nFreshman\n\n             \n\nOpen\n\n                    \n\n                    \n\n                        Close\n\nFall", "lemma": "Not include name require course Practicum Courses: All engineering design student take hour practicum courses. Enrollment practicum course require professional employment such internship co-op. Professional employment average minimum hour week work have duration least weeks. Professional employment include aspect design process such commercialization, conceptual design, manufacturing, modeling, process improvement, product design, product improvement, quality methods, testing, design validation. Practicum course be generally 300-level course term \u201cPracticum\u201d catalog description. Plan Study Freshman Open Close Fall"}

{"source": "Eval/Data-Science-SMO.txt", "text": "Data Science (Second Major Only)\n\nRequirements\n\nData Science is open to all students as a second major; this means that the student will have some other discipline as their primary major.\u00a0 Students whose primary major is in Computer Science, Software Engineering or Mathematics will find the Data Science program the easiest since there is considerable overlap between those programs and the Data Science requirements\u00a0 Students from other disciplines are also encouraged to participate, but will have to take more courses.\u00a0 All students are encouraged to take the individual courses in the program, regardless of whether they wish to fulfill the second major requirements.", "lemma": "Data Science (Second Major Only) Requirements Data Science be open student second major; mean student have other discipline primary major. Students primary major be Computer Science, Software Engineering Mathematics find Data Science program easy be considerable overlap program Data Science requirement Students other discipline be also encourage participate, have take more courses. student be encourage take individual course program, regardless wish fulfill second major requirements."}
{"source": "Eval/Data-Science-SMO.txt", "text": "Data Science requires 72 course credit hours and a senior capstone experience; these include 36 hours of Fundamental data science topics, 20 hours in Advanced topics, and 16 hours in Electives.\u00a0 The 36 fundamental credit hours and no more than 8 of the elective credit hours may be used to satisfy any requirements for another major (primary or secondary) or minor; students with a second major in Data Science cannot earn a minor in Data Science as well.\u00a0 Thus, the 20 Advanced credit hours and at least 8 Elective credit hours can only be used to satisfy technical and free electives of another major program.", "lemma": "Data Science require course credit hour senior capstone experience; include hour Fundamental data science topics, hour Advanced topics, hour Electives. fundamental credit hour more elective credit hour be use satisfy requirement major (primary secondary) minor; student second major Data Science cannot earn minor Data Science well. Thus, Advanced credit hour least Elective credit hour only be use satisfy technical free elective major program."}
{"source": "Eval/Data-Science-SMO.txt", "text": "Furthermore, Data Science majors are expected to complete a Senior Project or Senior Thesis in either their primary major or within either the Computer Science and Software Engineering Department or the Mathematics Department, and that this work includes a data science component.\n\nData Science Program Student Outcomes\n\n1.\u00a0\u00a0Provide leadership in both mathematical and computer science aspects of using data and solving related problems.\n\n2.\u00a0\u00a0Recognize ethical and professional responsibilities in data engineering situations and make informed judgments, which must consider the impact of engineering solutions in global, economic, environmental, and societal contexts.\n\n3.\u00a0\u00a0Function effectively on a team whose members together provide leadership, create a collaborative and inclusive environment, establish goals, plan tasks, and meet objectives.\n\n4.\u00a0\u00a0Analyze and interpret data to draw conclusions.", "lemma": "Furthermore, Data Science major be expect complete Senior Project Senior Thesis primary major Computer Science Software Engineering Department Mathematics Department, work include data science component. Data Science Program Student Outcomes Provide leadership mathematical computer science aspect use data solve related problems. Recognize ethical professional responsibility data engineering situation make inform judgments, consider impact engineering solution global, economic, environmental, societal contexts. Function effectively team member together provide leadership, create collaborative inclusive environment, establish goals, plan tasks, meet objectives. Analyze interpret data draw conclusions."}
{"source": "Eval/Data-Science-SMO.txt", "text": "4.\u00a0\u00a0Analyze and interpret data to draw conclusions.\n\n5.\u00a0\u00a0Explore and summarize large data sets using summary statistics and data visualization tools.\n\n6.\u00a0\u00a0Collaborate with domain experts to use data and machine learning to automate tasks and improve the efficiency of operations\n\n7.\u00a0\u00a0Communicate analysis results of large data sets.\n\n8.\u00a0\u00a0Acquire and apply new knowledge as needed, using appropriate learning strategies.\n\nData Science Program Educational Objectives\n\nGraduates from the data science program will be prepared for many types of careers in the world of data and be prepared for graduate study in data science and in closely related disciplines. In the early phases of their careers, we expect Rose-Hulman data science graduates to be:", "lemma": "Analyze interpret data draw conclusions. {"source": "Eval/Advising Timeline RHIT-checkpoint.txt", "text": "tip: Go to the Career Fair with the goal of learning rather than the goal of\ngetting a summer position. There\u2019s time, I promise. The Career Fair is wildly\nintimidating, even for me \u2013 hundreds of people milling around, long lines in\nfront of different booths, the noise, feeling underdressed or overdressed, and\non and on. Especially for introverts, the whole thing can be overwhelming. \nBut, if you\ngo with the goal of learning what the Career Fair is all about, I guarantee it\nwill feel better. {"source": "Eval/Biochemistry.txt", "text": "Biochemistry\n\nGraduates with a degree in biochemistry will be well prepared for employment, graduate study in biochemistry or other chemistry-related fields, or professional school. Biochemists are employed in research, quality control, design, sales and management. Many graduates pursue masters and doctoral degrees in biochemistry, medicinal chemistry, and in other life science fields. A biochemistry degree is excellent preparation for medical school and related fields, and also for careers in business, law or education.", "lemma": "Biochemistry Graduates degree biochemistry be well prepared employment, graduate study biochemistry other chemistry-related fields, professional school. A biochemistry degree be excellent preparation medical school relate fields, also career business, law education."}
{"source": "Eval/Biochemistry.txt", "text": "The curriculum at Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology provides a rigorous introduction to all subdisciplines of chemistry along with biochemistry and applied biology. Students have access to modern instrumentation along with a well-equipped biochemistry lab. Rose-Hulman students are introduced to modern computational methods beginning in the sophomore year. There are many opportunities for research or other individual projects, and students are encouraged to present their results at regional and national chemistry conferences. Close interaction with engineering departments provides students with a point of view not available at most other undergraduate institutions.\n\nStudent Outcomes\n\nStudent Outcomes are statements that describe what students are expected to have by the time of graduation.\n\nAn ability to design and conduct experiments as well as to analyze and interpret data.\n\nAn ability to recognize the professional and ethical responsibilities of a biochemist.", "lemma": "curriculum Rose-Hulman Institute Technology provide rigorous introduction subdisciplines chemistry biochemistry apply biology. Close interaction engineering department provide student point view not available most other undergraduate institutions. {"source": "Eval/Biomathematics.txt", "text": "Biomathematics\n\nMISSION STATEMENT\n\nAn increasing number of problems in the biological sciences are being solved using sophisticated mathematical and computational tools. The biomathematics degree blends mathematics, biology, and computer science in preparation for continued graduate studies and for careers in the quantitative life sciences.\u00a0The degree's mission is to provide a world class undergraduate education in applied mathematics used in support of the life sciences.\n\nThe degree's mission is supported and motivated by these facts:\n\nBiological data is being generated with unprecedented precision and in unfathomable volumes.\n\nQuantifying biological observations requires mathematical and statistical analysis.\n\nThe basic principles of complex biological systems support mathematical and computational modeling, which can lead to testable hypotheses and new discoveries.\n\nPROGRAM GOALS AND OBJECTIVES", "lemma": "Biomathematics MISSION STATEMENT increase number problem biological science be be solve use sophisticated mathematical computational tools. biomathematics degree blend mathematics, biology, computer science preparation continued graduate study career quantitative life sciences. degree's mission be provide world class undergraduate education applied mathematics use support life sciences. degree's mission be support motivate facts: Biological data be be generate unprecedented precision unfathomable volumes. Quantifying biological observation require mathematical statistical analysis. basic principle complex biological system support mathematical computational modeling, lead testable hypothesis new discoveries. PROGRAM GOALS AND OBJECTIVES"}
{"source": "Eval/Biomathematics.txt", "text": "PROGRAM GOALS AND OBJECTIVES\n\nThe biomathematics degree will provide a broad based undergraduate experience that 1) prepares students with a rigorous education in applied mathematics, 2) educates students in the fundamental principles of biology, 3) trains students to work in a computational arena, 4) introduces students to several of the sister disciplines of computational biology, mathematical biology, bioinformatics, systems biology, and biostatistics, and 5) guides students through an advanced undergraduate research project. The degree will also liberally educate students through the study of the humanities and social sciences. Students of the program will be encouraged to participate in external and internal research programs and industrial internships and/or co-ops.\n\nGraduates of the biomathematics program will have an ability to:", "lemma": "PROGRAM GOALS AND OBJECTIVES biomathematics degree provide broad base undergraduate experience prepares student rigorous education applied mathematics, educate student fundamental principle biology, train student work computational arena, introduces student several sister discipline computational biology, mathematical biology, bioinformatics, system biology, biostatistics, guide student advanced undergraduate research project. degree also liberally educate student study humanity social sciences. Students program be encourage participate external internal research program industrial internship co-ops. Graduates biomathematics program have ability to:"}
{"source": "Eval/Biomathematics.txt", "text": "Graduates of the biomathematics program will have an ability to:\n\nMathematically model, solve, and analyze problems in biomathematics.\n\nImplement computational approaches to solve and analyze problems in biomathematics.\n\nWrite lucidly about biomathematics.\n\nSpeak fluently and coherently about biomathematics.\n\nSynthesize new and previous knowledge through a capstone experience.\n\nPROGRAM OUTCOMES\n\nGraduates will be prepared for graduate study in any of the sister fields as well as for careers in the quantitative life sciences. Each graduate will complete a capstone research experience that will culminate in a written report and a public presentation.", "lemma": "Graduates biomathematics program have ability to: Mathematically model, solve, analyze problem biomathematics. Implement computational approach solve analyze problem biomathematics. Write lucidly biomathematics. Speak fluently coherently biomathematics. Synthesize new previous knowledge capstone experience. PROGRAM OUTCOMES Graduates be prepare graduate study sister field as well career quantitative life sciences. graduate complete capstone research experience culminate write report public presentation."}

{"source": "Eval/Biomathematics.txt", "text": "FOCUS AREAS\n\nStudents earning a major in Biomathematics are encouraged to gain depth in a particular mathematical or\u00a0scientific area. By pursuing focused coursework in the following suggested areas, students will advance their\u00a0preparation for graduate studies or careers in mathematical life sciences. Gaining depth through advanced electives also provides biomathematics students with an opportunity to apply knowledge gained through BMTH\u00a0coursework. {"source": "Eval/Student-Handbook11.txt", "text": "pg. 12 governing general student conduct are discussed in the appropriate student \nhandbooks.  \n2. There are two major areas of jurisdiction. The Dean of Students and the \nDean's staff handle cases of Non -Academic Misconduct. Individual faculty \nmembers and the Institute Rules and Discipline Committee handle cases of \nAcademic Misconduct. All cases of misconduct must be reported to the Dean of Students.  \n3. Whenever a student is charged with N on-Academic Misconduct, a disciplinary \nconference will be scheduled with the Dean of Students.  \n4. Any student charged with misconduct is urged to consult with the Dean of Students or the Chairperson of the Institute Rules and Discipline Committee to be informed of the procedures that will be followed and to receive", "lemma": "pg. govern general student conduct be discuss appropriate student handbooks. be major area jurisdiction. {"source": "Eval/Software%20Engineering.txt", "text": "Software Engineering\n\nSoftware engineering is the creation of software using a process similar to other engineering disciplines. It allows for software to be reliable and developed within time and cost estimates. The software engineering curriculum prepares students for a career in reliable, economical software development.\n\nProgramming is only one phase (construction) of software engineering. There are many other aspects of the software engineering process, such as requirements definition, architectural design, and quality assurance, which need to be applied in order to develop reliable software on time and within budget constraints. The software engineering curriculum provides students a solid background in both the theory and practice of all phases in the software engineering process, beginning with their first course of study in the Department of Computer Science and Software Engineering, and continuing to the end of the senior year.", "lemma": "Software Engineering Software engineering be creation software use process similar other engineering disciplines. allow software be reliable develop time cost estimates. software engineering curriculum prepare student career reliable, economical software development. Programming be only phase (construction) software engineering. be many other aspect software engineering process, such requirement definition, architectural design, quality assurance, need be apply order develop reliable software time budget constraints. software engineering curriculum provide student solid background theory practice phase software engineering process, begin first course study Department Computer Science Software Engineering, continue end senior year."}
{"source": "Eval/Software%20Engineering.txt", "text": "Since software is a non-physical product developed and executed on computers, the software engineering curriculum has computer science as its primary engineering science. The computer science courses taken by software engineering majors include the study of algorithms, data structures, database concepts, computer architecture, programming languages and operating systems. Software engineering majors also complete important courses in other closely related fields, such as discrete mathematics, digital logic design, and engineering statistics.", "lemma": "software be non-physical product develop execute computers, software engineering curriculum have computer science primary engineering science. computer science course take software engineering major include study algorithms, data structures, database concepts, computer program language operate systems. Software engineering major also complete important course other closely related fields, such discrete mathematics, digital logic design, engineering statistics."}
{"source": "Eval/Software%20Engineering.txt", "text": "Coverage of software engineering topics begins in a three-term introduction to software development during the freshman and sophomore years. This study continues with coverage of core software engineering areas in the junior year, including software requirements, software architecture, software design, software project management, software construction, software maintenance, software evolution, software quality assurance, and formal methods in software specification and design. All of these courses include individual and team projects relevant to that particular area of software engineering. These projects generally include both written and oral presentations, building upon a technical communication course which introduces the student to the skills necessary for this important aspect of being a software professional. Throughout the senior year, a capstone team project develops and delivers software for a \u201creal-world\u201d client, which is put on display locally at a public exposition.", "lemma": "Coverage software engineering topic begin three-term introduction software development freshman sophomore years. study continue coverage core software engineering area junior year, include software requirements, software architecture, software design, software project management, software construction, software maintenance, software evolution, software quality assurance, formal method software specification design. course include individual team project relevant particular area software project generally include write oral presentations, building technical communication course introduce student skill necessary important aspect be software professional. senior year, capstone team project develop delivers software \u201creal-world\u201d client, be put display locally public exposition."}
{"source": "Eval/Software%20Engineering.txt", "text": "Throughout society, software exists for a wide variety of application domain areas. Each student is required to take at least three courses in a particular application domain, so that RHIT software engineering graduates can more effectively apply the software engineering principles they learn to that domain area. Students can choose from a variety of domain areas, including engineering, scientific and commercial applications.\n\nCourses in various computer science topics such as computer graphics, artificial intelligence, computer networks, computer vision, web-based information systems, and cryptography are among those available as advanced electives. In addition, free elective courses allow students to tailor their undergraduate education to their specific goals.", "lemma": "society, software exist wide variety application domain student be require take least course particular application domain, RHIT software engineering graduate more effectively apply software engineering principle learn domain Students choose variety domain include engineering, scientific commercial applications. Courses various computer science topic such computer graphics, artificial intelligence, computer networks, computer vision, web-based information systems, cryptography be available advanced electives. addition, free elective course allow student tailor undergraduate education specific goals."}
{"source": "Eval/Software%20Engineering.txt", "text": "The department has its own local area network. This network is connected to the campus-wide network and the Internet. Laboratory machines are mostly Sun Ultra workstations. Software engineering majors have unlimited access to the department\u2019s laboratories. Software engineering students are frequently employed by the computing center as user consultants and by the department as system managers and course assistants.\n\nThe student chapter of the Association for Computing Machinery provides seminars and other technical activities throughout the year. The national honor society in the computing and engineering disciplines, Upsilon Pi Epsilon and Tau Beta Pi, both have chapters at Rose-Hulman. Software engineering majors are also eligible to join the Order of the Engineer, which focuses on the ethical and professional responsibilities of an engineer, during the spring of their last year of study.\n\nSoftware Engineering Program Educational Objectives", "lemma": "department have own local area network. network be connect campus-wide network Internet. {"source": "Eval/ROTC-Air%20Force.txt", "text": "ROTC: Air Force\n\nAir Force ROTC is designed as a four year training program that culminates in a student's becoming an Officer in the United States Air Force. This program is designed to run concurrently with the four year college curriculum and is open to all college students at no obligation.*\n\nWe also offer modified programs which can be completed in three or two years which also earn a commission in the Air Force. Once students have completed Air Force ROTC and college requirements they are off to serve at least the next four years in leadership positions throughout the Air Force.\n\nBased on individual situations, Air Force ROTC will ask for an obligation before more advanced training or monies are paid to a student. Until such time, the classes are free and at no obligation-contact Air Force ROTC for more details.", "lemma": "ROTC: Air Force Air Force ROTC be design year training program culminate student's become Officer United States Air Force. program be design run concurrently year college curriculum be open college student obligation.* also offer modified program be complete year also earn commission Air Force. Once student have complete Air Force ROTC college requirement be serve least next year leadership position Air Force. Based individual situations, Air Force ROTC ask obligation more advanced training monies be pay student. such class be free obligation-contact Air Force ROTC more details."}
{"source": "Eval/ROTC-Air%20Force.txt", "text": "SCHOLARSHIPS", "lemma": "SCHOLARSHIPS"}
{"source": "Eval/ROTC-Air%20Force.txt", "text": "The Air Force is looking for the best and brightest students the country has to offer. To assist these students with their college education, a variety of scholarships are offered on a nationwide competitive basis. Scholarship winners attending Rose-Hulman can receive up to the full cost of tuition, plus payment of most school fees. Scholarships also pay for books along with a monthly tax-free stipend, during the school year. In addition, Rose-Hulman offers financial incentives to students bringing their ROTC scholarship to Rose-Hulman. For more information on Air Force scholarships, contact Rose-Hulman Admissions or Air Force ROTC Detachment 218 at Indiana State University, Technology Center Room 203, Terre Haute, IN 47809-2245. Phone (812) 237-2657.", "lemma": "Air Force be look best bright student country have offer. assist student college education, variety scholarship be offer nationwide competitive basis. Scholarship winner attend Rose-Hulman receive up full cost tuition, payment most school fees. Scholarships also pay book monthly tax-free stipend, school year. addition, Rose-Hulman offer financial incentive student bring ROTC scholarship Rose-Hulman. more information Air Force scholarships, contact Rose-Hulman Admissions Air Force ROTC Detachment Indiana State University, Technology Center Room Terre Haute, IN 47809-2245. Phone 237-2657."}
{"source": "Eval/ROTC-Air%20Force.txt", "text": "The Air Force ROTC courses are designed to develop the leadership and management skills required to be an effective Air Force officer. Topics range from Air Force history to ethics and values. The curriculum is separated into four (4) major areas:\n\nProfession of Arms\u00a0Designed specifically for the continued development of professional knowledge and skills unique to the Air Force profession. Subject areas include officership, military law, laws of armed conflict, military customs and courtesies, and the individual's role in supporting organizational and Air Force policies.", "lemma": "Air Force ROTC course be design develop leadership management skill require be effective Air Force officer. Topics range Air Force history ethic values. curriculum be separate (4) major areas: Profession Arms Designed specifically continued development professional knowledge skill unique Air Force profession. Subject area include officership, military law, law armed conflict, military custom courtesies, individual's role support organizational Air Force policies."}
{"source": "Eval/ROTC-Air%20Force.txt", "text": "Communications Skills\u00a0Designed specifically to enhance professional development, which is integrated throughout the AFROTC curriculum. Emphasis is on a progressive study of the various communication skills required of Air Force junior officers. The curriculum is designed to provide both instruction and application of principles and concepts in written communications, staff communication instruments, oral communication, and the nature and art of effective listening.\n\nLeadership Studies\u00a0Designed to examine aspects of military leadership and management functions as a part of the overall concept of leadership. An examination of leader variables and characteristics provides a lead-in to a protracted study of leadership theory. Leadership and management skills are developed and applied in Leadership Laboratory and cadet corps activities. Leadership training is emphasized at Field Training where team sports, military drill, and special leadership problems are mandatory.", "lemma": "Communications Skills Designed specifically enhance professional development, be integrate AFROTC curriculum. Emphasis be progressive study various communication skill require Air Force junior officers. curriculum be design provide instruction application principle concept write communications, staff communication instruments, oral communication, nature art effective listening. Leadership Studies Designed examine aspect military leadership management function part overall concept leadership. examination leader variable characteristic provide lead-in protracted study leadership theory. Leadership management skill be develop apply Leadership Laboratory cadet corp activities. Leadership training be emphasize Field Training team sports, military drill, special leadership problem be mandatory."}
{"source": "Eval/ROTC-Air%20Force.txt", "text": "Military Studies/International Security Studies\u00a0Designed to develop an understanding of the nature of conflict and how the United States military forces, particularly aerospace forces, are developed, organized, and employed. Subjects include the need for national security, the evolution and formulation of American defense policy and strategy, regional security issues, and joint doctrine.\n\nBenefits\n\nAir Force ROTC classes, text books, and uniforms are free to all fully-enrolled cadets. Once enrolled as a full member of the program, cadets are eligible to attend a variety of professional development programs during the summer months. Successful completion of the Air Force ROTC program results in a commission as a Second Lieutenant in the active duty US Air Force.\n\nPlan of Study\n\nFreshman\n\n             \n\nOpen\n\n                    \n\n                    \n\n                        Close\n\nFall", "lemma": "Military Studies/International Security Studies Designed develop understanding nature conflict United States military forces, particularly aerospace forces, be developed, organized, employed. Anyone planning to operate a UAS on Institution property must contact the \nOffice of Safety and Security thirty (30) days in advance in order to assess the \nInstitution's ability to comply with revised FAA requirement, or meet local \ncompliance requirements. That the hearing was not fair (because of biases of members of the Rules and \nDiscipline Committee, etc.)  \n3. That the findings of the hearing were not accurate (because evidence was overlooked or improper evidence taken into account.)  \n4. {"source": "Eval/Student-Handbook18.txt", "text": "1. A student who is suspended and wishes to appeal this ruling to the Faculty \nmust submit a written appeal to the Chairperson of the Institute Rules and \nDiscipline Committee within five business days of the Committee 's ruling.  \n2. The Chairperson will provide the student with a copy of the minutes or a \nrecording of the hearing.  \n3. Within five business days of receiving the minutes or recording, the student \nmust make a written appeal to the President of the Institute, who will \ndistribute copies to the Dean of Students, the Chairperson of the Institute Rules and Discipline Committee and other persons involved.  \n4. The case will be heard at either a regular or a special Institute Meeting at the", "lemma": "A student be suspend wish appeal ruling Faculty submit write appeal Chairperson Institute Rules Discipline Committee business day Committee ruling. {"source": "Eval/Student-Handbook18.txt", "text": "4. The case will be heard at either a regular or a special Institute Meeting at the \ndiscretion of the President, who wi ll preside at the appeal.  \n5. All parties in the case will be permitted to appear at the hearing to make \nstatements and answer questions. The student may be accompanied by a \nfaculty member or other person affiliated with the Institute whom the \nstudent selects  to serve as counsel.  \n6. The proceedings will begin with a report by the Chairperson of the Institute \nRules and Discipline Committee, summarizing the previous hearing(s). Then the parties involved shall make their statements of appeal and answer \nquestions from the Faculty. Since this is an appeal and not a re -hearing,", "lemma": "case be hear regular special Institute Meeting discretion President, wi ll preside appeal. {"source": "Eval/Student-Handbook18.txt", "text": "questions from the Faculty. Since this is an appeal and not a re -hearing, \nwitnesses will not be re -heard nor evidence reviewed. The focus will be on \nerrors in the previous hearing, unfairness, or mitigating circumstances.  \n7. With all parties dismissed, the Faculty shall  discuss its decision. Any faculty \nmember directly involved in the case will be excused from this final \ndeliberation. The decision shall be arrived at by simple majority vote. At the \nrequest of any faculty member, the vote will be by secret ballot.  \n8. {"source": "Eval/About Our Students RHIT-checkpoint.txt", "text": "information to your academic advising syllabus.\nRisk Averse\nWhile \nthe idea of risk taking may apply more to a sense of danger in their \nphysical and online environments, it may transfer to the context of \nlearning.\u00a0 Your advisees may avoid challenging projects, courses, \nor majors so as not to fail.\n                Reminding your advisees that failure is an important \npart of the learning process can help them ease into necessary risk \ntaking while promoting a growth mindset.\nFinancially conservative\nReminding\n your advisees that they have invested a great deal in campus resources,\n and that they should get a return on their investment.\u00a0 If your \nadvisees have low midterm grades, consider reminding them how much it \ncosts to repeat a\n                course.", "lemma": "information academic advising syllabus. In doing so, it provides learning experiences that, in addition to their intrinsic value, enrich a scientific and technical education.\n\nEducational Objectives\n\nWithin the context of a liberal education, the department fosters in its students the desire and the ability to:\n\nthink critically, forming cogent, informed opinions, defining and solving problems with an awareness that societal processes are complex and interactive;\n\ncommunicate effectively\u00a0to diverse audiences, including those from other cultures and communities;", "lemma": "Philosophy Religion Psychology Spanish Theatre Drama MISSION STATEMENT enable student become creative, sophisticated thinkers, active citizens, effective leader global community, department contribute broad liberal education, introduce student wide array discipline tradition humanity social sciences. do so, provide learning experience that, addition intrinsic value, enrich scientific technical education. {"source": "Eval/Humanities,%20Social%20Sciences,%20and%20the%20Arts.txt", "text": "Graduation Requirements\n\n1. General\n\nAll students must take a minimum of nine courses (36 credits) in Humanities, Social Sciences, and the Arts (HSSA). These courses may be chosen from the HSSA offerings, within the restrictions below.\n\nStudents must take a course in at least two of the three areas of study (Humanities & Arts, Social Sciences, and Modern Languages).\n\n2.\u00a0All students must take a First-Year Writing Seminar.\n\nHUM H190 First-Year Writing Seminar 4R-0L-4C F, W\u00a0\u00a0\n\nFirst-year students at Rose-Hulman take a writing seminar to help them transition into college-level writing and build their critical reading and thinking skills. Writing seminars are themed around engaging and timely topics.", "lemma": "Graduation Requirements General All student take minimum course (36 credits) Humanities, Social Sciences, Arts course be choose HSSA offerings, restriction below. Students take course least area study (Humanities Arts, Social Sciences, Modern Languages). All student take First-Year Writing Seminar. HUM H190 First-Year Writing Seminar 4R-0L-4C F, W First-year student Rose-Hulman take writing seminar help transition college-level writing build critical reading think skills. Writing seminar be theme engage timely topics."}
{"source": "Eval/Humanities,%20Social%20Sciences,%20and%20the%20Arts.txt", "text": "Choosing themes that interest them, students cultivate scholarly skills and habits that will serve them throughout their college careers and beyond: considering diverse perspectives; reading for deep and nuanced understanding; exploring research questions with an open mind; engaging with others' ideas while developing their own; writing for specific audiences and purposes; revising existing writing to incorporate feedback and new information; and crafting well-supported, appealing arguments.\n\n3. Technical and Professional Communication is a requirement for most majors, and counts toward the total requirement of 9 HSSA courses.\n\nModern Language\n\nStudents who elect to take a modern language should note the following special requirements:", "lemma": "Choosing theme interest them, student cultivate scholarly skill habit serve college career beyond: consider diverse perspectives; reading deep nuanced understanding; explore research question open mind; engage others' idea develop own; writing specific audience purposes; revise exist write incorporate feedback new information; craft well-supported, appeal arguments. {"source": "Eval/Humanities,%20Social%20Sciences,%20and%20the%20Arts.txt", "text": "Modern Language\n\nStudents who elect to take a modern language should note the following special requirements:\n\nA minimum of two terms of the same language (or the equivalent thereof) must be completed in order to apply modern language credits toward Humanities and Social Sciences requirements. If only SPAN L111, JAPN L111 or GER L111 is completed, that course will not be allowed to satisfy an HSSA requirement. \u00a0For transfer credit, a single modern language course at 4 credit hours may be used to satisfy an HSSA requirement if it is higher than the entry level course (L111) in that language. Example: Transfer credit awarded for SPAN L113 could be used to satisfy one HSSA course requirement.", "lemma": "Modern Language Students elect take modern language note following special requirements: A minimum term same language (or equivalent thereof) be complete order apply modern language credit Humanities Social Sciences requirements. only SPAN L111, JAPN L111 GER L111 be completed, course not be allow satisfy HSSA requirement. transfer credit, single modern language course credit hour be use satisfy HSSA requirement be high entry level course (L111) language. Example: Transfer credit award SPAN L113 be use satisfy HSSA course requirement."}
{"source": "Eval/Humanities,%20Social%20Sciences,%20and%20the%20Arts.txt", "text": "HSSA credit will not be awarded for a lower-level language course until the student takes and passes the next course in the language sequence with a grade of C or better.\n\nNo more than 16 credits of modern language may be counted toward HSSA requirements.\n\nStudents may not earn modern language credit in their native languages.\n\nNote: Students planning to study abroad should be sure to have their program approved ahead of time by the head of the HSSA Department and by the head of the Department in which they are majoring.\n\nMinors \n\nStudents may elect a minor in most of the HSSA Department's disciplines. In addition, several interdisciplinary minors are available. (See below.)\u00a0 A student taking a minor in HSSA must take a minimum of ten to eleven courses.\n\nMinor", "lemma": "HSSA credit not be award lower-level language course student take pass next course language sequence grade C better.
