{"source": "Eval/Humanities,%20Social%20Sciences,%20and%20the%20Arts.txt", "text": "Minor\n\nA student may elect to take an Minor in Anthropology, East Asian Studies, Economics, European Studies, Geography, German, History, Japanese, Language and Literature, Latin American Studies Philosophy and Religion, Political Science, Psychology, Spanish or Theatre and Drama by concentrating 5 to 7 HSS courses in that area. NOTE: All Minors require taking one additional HSS course, for a minimum of 40 HSSA credits (44 in the case of foreign languages). See the specific requirements listed under each Minor. Successful completion of the Minor is indicated on the student's grade transcript. A student interested in pursuing a Minor should consult with the appropriate Minor Adviser, listed below, for aid in planning a course schedule. No courses counted toward fulfilling the requirements for one minor may be counted in fulfilling the requirements of another minor.", "lemma": "Minor A student elect take Minor Anthropology, East Asian Studies, Economics, European Studies, Geography, German, History, Japanese, Language Literature, Latin American Studies Philosophy Religion, Political Science, Psychology, Spanish Theatre Drama concentrate HSS course area. NOTE: All Minors require take additional HSS course, minimum HSSA credit (44 case foreign languages). See specific requirement list Minor. Successful completion Minor be indicate student's grade transcript. A student interested pursue Minor consult appropriate Minor Adviser, list below, aid plan course schedule. No course count fulfil requirement minor be count fulfil requirement minor."}

{"source": "Eval/Humanities,%20Social%20Sciences,%20and%20the%20Arts.txt", "text": "International Studies Major (IS) (second major only)\n\nIn the 21st century, technical work occurs increasingly in an international and multi-lingual arena. The International Studies major provides Rose-Hulman students with the opportunity to complement their primary major with a second major that prepares them for an interdependent, multicultural, and transnational world. Courses in the major focus on economic, cultural, and social processes that take place among nations and world regions. Topics may include globalization, post-colonialism, communication, migration, and environmental change.", "lemma": "International Studies Major (IS) (second major only) century, technical work occur increasingly international multi-lingual arena. International Studies major provide Rose-Hulman student opportunity complement primary major second major prepare interdependent, multicultural, transnational world. Courses major focus economic, cultural, social process take place nation world regions. Topics include globalization, post-colonialism, communication, migration, environmental change."}
{"source": "Eval/Humanities,%20Social%20Sciences,%20and%20the%20Arts.txt", "text": "The IS major promotes the critical understanding of the historical and contemporary entanglements of diverse cultures around the world. It offers theoretical tools and models practical steps with which to assess competing claims about the world. Students will participate in the analysis of complex situations in which the evidence may be ambiguous and in which there may be no one clear answer. They will learn to devise questions that guide productive research into such situations.\n\nLearning Outcomes:\n\nRecognition of cultural diversity requires the comparison and analysis of historical, cultural, political, social, or regional differences. \n\n\n\nAnalyze a socio-cultural artifact, event, or system of a society different from your own.\n\nCompare socio-cultural artifacts or systems in two or more cultures/world regions/civilizations\n\nCarry out a project involving meaningful contact with students, colleagues, clients, or sponsors abroad.", "lemma": "IS major promotes critical understanding historical contemporary entanglement diverse culture world. offer theoretical tool model practical step assess compete claim world. Students participate analysis complex situation evidence be ambiguous be clear answer. learn devise question guide productive research such situations. Learning Outcomes: Recognition cultural diversity require comparison analysis historical, cultural, political, social, regional differences. Analyze socio-cultural artifact, event, system society different own. Compare socio-cultural artifact system more cultures/world regions/civilizations Carry out project involve meaningful contact students, colleagues, clients, sponsor abroad."}
{"source": "Eval/Humanities,%20Social%20Sciences,%20and%20the%20Arts.txt", "text": "Carry out a project involving meaningful contact with students, colleagues, clients, or sponsors abroad.\n\nTransnational and global awareness requires an understanding of the ideas, systems, processes, or trends that have created a globally interdependent world. \n\n\n\nExplain the global causes or effects of an action or decision by nation-states, corporations, groups of people, or other actors\n\nArgue for a course of action\u2014political, economic, or otherwise\u2014when given an international situation/case study\n\nIndependent Study of global issues requires the application of appropriate analytic vocabulary, methodologies, or critical frameworks from the Humanities or the Social Sciences \n\n\n\nAssemble and evaluate resources for research in international studies.\n\nDesign and carry out a research project analyzing a significant international or global issue, system, process, or event.", "lemma": "Carry out project involve meaningful contact students, colleagues, clients, sponsor abroad. The courses have\u00a0international processes, comparisons, or other connections as a central focus. {"source": "Eval/Humanities,%20Social%20Sciences,%20and%20the%20Arts.txt", "text": "First year students at Rose-Hulman take a writing seminar to help them transition into college-level writing and build their critical reading and thinking skills. Writing seminars are themed around engaging and timely topics. Choosing themes that interest them, students cultivate scholarly skills and habits that will serve them throughout their college careers and beyond: considering diverse perspectives; reading for deep and nuanced understanding; exploring research questions with an open mind; engaging with others' ideas while developing their own; writing for specific audiences and purposes; revising existing writing to incorporate feedback and new information; and crafting well-supported, appealing arguments.\n\nPrerequisite Notes:\n\n                \n\nHUM H199 Introduction to International Studies 4R-OL-4C S", "lemma": "First year student Rose-Hulman take writing seminar help transition college-level writing build critical reading think skills. Writing seminar be theme engage timely topics. Choosing theme interest them, student cultivate scholarly skill habit serve college career beyond: consider diverse perspectives; reading deep nuanced understanding; explore research question open mind; engage others' idea develop own; writing specific audience purposes; revise exist write incorporate feedback new information; craft well-supported, appeal arguments. Prerequisite Notes: HUM H199 Introduction International Studies S"}
{"source": "Eval/Humanities,%20Social%20Sciences,%20and%20the%20Arts.txt", "text": "HUM H199 Introduction to International Studies 4R-OL-4C S\n\nIntroduces International Studies as an interdisciplinary field of inquiry and scholarship. Students will explore multiple disciplines in the humanities, social sciences, and arts, applying their analytical and interpretive frameworks to global regions, cultural institutions, and sociohistorical processes important to today's world events and contemporary debates. As an inherently interdisciplinary course, Introduction to International Studies can be taken for either humanities (H) or social science (S) credit. Same as SOC S199; students may not receive credit for both.\n\nHUM H230 Engineering Design Social Capstone  2R-OL-2C", "lemma": "HUM H199 Introduction International Studies 4R-OL-4C S Introduces International Studies interdisciplinary field inquiry scholarship. {"source": "Eval/mechanical-engineering.txt", "text": "Mechanical Engineering\n\nGraduate Studies \u2013 Mechanical Engineering\n\nThese programs have been designed to build upon a student\u2019s undergraduate background and provide additional depth and breadth in the challenging and versatile profession of Mechanical Engineering. The department offers two graduate path alternatives. The Master of Science in Mechanical Engineering (MSME) degree program is a traditional thesis-based approach whereby the student pursues both research and course work culminating in the preparation and oral defense of a written thesis. The Master of Mechanical Engineering (MME) degree is a course-based master\u2019s program, which requires additional coursework in lieu of a traditional thesis.", "lemma": "Mechanical Engineering Graduate Studies \u2013 Mechanical Engineering program have be design build student\u2019s undergraduate background provide additional depth breadth challenging versatile profession Mechanical Engineering. department offer graduate path Master Science Mechanical Engineering (MSME) degree program be traditional thesis-based approach whereby student pursue research course work culminate preparation oral defense write Master Mechanical Engineering (MME) degree be course-based master\u2019s program, require additional coursework lieu traditional thesis."}
{"source": "Eval/mechanical-engineering.txt", "text": "The objective of both programs, the Master of Mechanical Engineering and Master of Science in Mechanical Engineering, is to prepare graduates for early career advancement in the field of Mechanical Engineering by building upon their undergraduate training with advanced coursework and concentrated study of problems and topics relevant to the field.\n\nMaster of Science in Mechanical Engineering (MSME)\n\nBy the end of their program, MSME students should be able to:\n\nIdentify, formulate, and solve high-level mechanical engineering problems.\n\nDemonstrate the ability to effectively communicate theories and methodologies related to mechanical engineering with technical audiences.\n\nEvaluate and analyze relevant scientific literature to stay current in their field of study.\n\nConduct independent research and evaluate, interpret, and discuss research outcomes.\n\nRequirements\n\n36 credits of formal coursework\n\n12 credits of thesis coursework", "lemma": "objective programs, Master Mechanical Engineering Master Science Mechanical Engineering, be prepare graduate early career advancement field Mechanical Engineering build undergraduate training advanced coursework concentrate study problem topic relevant field. {"source": "Eval/Frequently Asked Questions RHIT.txt", "text": "Calculus I before going into Physics II.\u00a0 We do not do a whole lot with\ncalculus at the beginning of Physics II, but around mid-term we do several\nthings with multivariable calculus covered in Calculus II.\u00a0 If a student\nstill wants to take Physics II without passing Calculus I, it is possible to do\nthis but it is not recommended.\u00a0 The student must talk with his Physics II\ninstructor and they both need to understand the situation.\u00a0 If the student\nand faculty member are okay with the situation, a pre-req waiver can be completed\nand filed.\u00a0 The student can then enroll in Physics II.\u00a0 Looking at\nthe history of this situation, sometimes it works, sometimes it does not.", "lemma": "Calculus go Physics II. do not do whole lot calculus beginning Physics II, mid-term do several thing multivariable calculus cover Calculus II. student still want take Physics II pass Calculus I, be possible do be not recommended. student talk Physics II instructor need understand situation. student faculty member be okay situation, pre-req waiver be complete filed. student then enroll Physics II. {"source": "Eval/Electrical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "Electrical Engineering\n\nElectrical Engineering (EE) is a professional engineering discipline that deals with the study and application of electricity, electronics, and electromagnetism. Common EE tasks include designing communication systems, energy conversion and power delivery, control systems applications, design of analog and digital systems, and others. Below is a recommended plan of study for EE.\n\nEE Program Educational Objectives\n\nElectrical Engineering graduates shall:\n\nPractice excellence in their profession using a systems approach encompassing technological, economic, ethical, environmental, social, and human issues within a changing global environment;\n\nFunction independently and in leadership positions within multidisciplinary teams;\n\nContinue life-long learning by acquiring new knowledge, mastering emerging technologies, and using\u00a0 appropriate tools and methods;\n\nAdapt and independently extend their learning to excel in fields about which they are passionate;", "lemma": "Electrical Engineering Electrical Engineering (EE) be professional engineering discipline deal study application electricity, electronics, electromagnetism. Common EE task include design communication systems, energy conversion power delivery, control system applications, design analog digital systems, others. Below be recommended plan study EE. EE Program Educational Objectives Electrical Engineering graduate shall: Practice excellence profession use system approach encompass technological, economic, ethical, environmental, social, human issue change global environment; Function independently leadership position multidisciplinary teams; Continue life-long learning acquire new knowledge, master emerge technologies, use appropriate tool methods; Adapt independently extend learning excel field be passionate;"}
{"source": "Eval/Electrical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "Adapt and independently extend their learning to excel in fields about which they are passionate;\n\nStrengthen teams and communities through collaboration, effective communication, public service, and leadership.\n\nEE Student Learning Outcomes\n\nAt the time of graduation, students will have demonstrated:\n\nan ability to identify, formulate, and solve complex engineering problems by applying principles of engineering, science, and mathematics\n\nan ability to apply engineering design to produce solutions that meet specified needs with consideration of public health, safety, welfare, as well as global, cultural, social, environmental, and economic factors\n\nan ability to communicate effectively with a range of audiences\n\nan ability to recognize ethical and professional responsibilities in engineering situations and make informed judgments, which must consider the impact of engineering solutions in global, economic, environmental, and societal contexts", "lemma": "Adapt independently extend learning excel field be passionate; Strengthen team community collaboration, effective communication, public service, leadership. {"source": "Eval/Physics.txt", "text": "Physics\n\nThe physics curriculum is designed to develop a strong foundation in classical and modern physics, which will serve as a basis for future specialization, for additional study at the graduate level, and for design and development work in industrial laboratories. The curriculum emphasizes basic physical concepts, and includes extensive work in mathematics and related areas. Laboratory facilities are available for work in optics, acoustics, X-ray diffraction, nuclear physics, and solid-state physics. Course topics included in the curriculum are Many Particle Physics, Physical Optics, Biophysics, Biomedical Optics, Theoretical Mechanics, Electromagnetism, Celestial Mechanics, Acoustics, Microsensors, Semiconductor Materials and Devices, X-rays and Crystalline Materials, Electro-Optics, and Laser Physics.", "lemma": "Physics physic curriculum be design develop strong foundation classical modern physics, serve basis future specialization, additional study graduate level, design development work industrial laboratories. curriculum emphasize basic physical concepts, include extensive work mathematics related areas. Laboratory facility be available work optics, acoustics, X-ray diffraction, nuclear physics, solid-state physics. Course topic include curriculum be Many Particle Physics, Physical Optics, Biophysics, Biomedical Optics, Theoretical Mechanics, Electromagnetism, Celestial Mechanics, Acoustics, Microsensors, Semiconductor Materials Devices, X-rays Crystalline Materials, Electro-Optics, Laser Physics."}
{"source": "Eval/Physics.txt", "text": "The Physics program places an emphasis on laboratory courses with a hands-on approach. The students have the opportunity to take a variety of courses in disciplines such as math and chemistry allowing them to tailor their education. The Physics curriculum is flexible enough that one can double major in computer science, mathematics, electrical engineering, and mechanical engineering. National interest in our program has been generated by our basic physics courses that use new methodologies of teaching such as studio format lectures.", "lemma": "Physics program place emphasis laboratory course hands-on approach. student have opportunity take variety course discipline such math chemistry allow tailor education. Physics curriculum be flexible enough double major computer science, mathematics, electrical engineering, mechanical engineering. National interest program have be generate basic physic course use new methodology teach such studio format lectures."}
{"source": "Eval/Physics.txt", "text": "We have a wide range of research programs accessible to undergraduates including areas such as: Astronomy, Solid State Devices, Electro-optics, Non-linear Optics, X-ray absorption, Semiconductor Materials and Devices, Magnetics, Chaos, Lasers, Fiber Optics, Holography, Microsensors. In addition, we are very successful in placing our students in summer internship positions with various research facilities such as NASA, Argonne National Laboratory, Sandia National Laboratory, National Radio Astronomy Observatory, and CSPAAR.\n\nPhysics Student Learning Outcomes\n\nFundamental Knowledge: Demonstrate a broad working knowledge base in physics.\n\nProblem Solving: Demonstrate competency in applying the skills and knowledge necessary for scientific solutions to mathematical, scientific, and engineering problems.", "lemma": "have wide range research program accessible undergraduate include area such as: Astronomy, Solid State Devices, Electro-optics, Non-linear Optics, X-ray absorption, Semiconductor Materials Devices, Magnetics, Chaos, Lasers, Fiber Optics, Holography, Microsensors. addition, be very successful place student summer internship position various research facility such NASA, Argonne National Laboratory, Sandia National Laboratory, National Radio Astronomy Observatory, CSPAAR. Physics Student Learning Outcomes Fundamental Knowledge: Demonstrate broad working knowledge base physics. Problem Solving: Demonstrate competency apply skill knowledge necessary scientific solution mathematical, scientific, engineering problems."}
{"source": "Eval/Physics.txt", "text": "Experiments: Design and conduct experiments and interpret and analyze acquired data while demonstrating understanding of the underlying scientific theory, method, and process.\n\nModeling: Formulate questions and produce an appropriate physical model to represent and describe real-world physics problems.\n\nEthics: Explain professional and ethical responsibility to the field and public and behave with integrity and accountability.\n\nCommunication: \u00a0Communicate effectively, accurately, and succinctly scientific problems and solutions to a range of audiences via appropriate methods.\n\nPHYSICS\n\nSUMMARY OF GRADUATION REQUIREMENTS FOR PHYSICS MAJORS\n\nAll the courses listed above by the number.\n\nThe program must be approved by the advisor.\n\nEleven credits of physics courses, besides those listed by number. At least one of these credits must be directed research (PH290 or PH490).", "lemma": "Experiments: Design conduct experiment interpret analyze acquire data demonstrate understanding underlie scientific theory, method, process. {"source": "Eval/Physics.txt", "text": "Overall aim of the Certificate\n\nA certificate holder will understand how semiconductor devices work, have practical experience in the main stages of device production, have practical experience in the more common forms of device testing and characterization, and have broad understanding of the mechanical and chemical properties of the material used.\n\nA Certificate holder will be well suited for jobs requiring an understanding of semiconductor devices and their production. These jobs include not only those directly related to device fabrication, but also those involved with testing and trouble-shooting electronic equipment and the design of machines that contain electronic equipment. The experience in simple device fabrication that the Certificate provides is particularly useful for future engineers in \u201cprocess\u201d industries.\n\nPlan of Study\n\nFreshman\n\n             \n\nOpen\n\n                    \n\n                    \n\n                        Close\n\nFall", "lemma": "Overall aim Certificate A certificate holder understand semiconductor device have practical experience main stage device production, have practical experience more common form device testing characterization, have broad understanding mechanical chemical property material used. {"source": "Eval/Optical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "Optical Engineering", "lemma": "Optical Engineering"}
{"source": "Eval/Optical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "The science of light, once confined to research labs and science fiction novels, has found its way into our everyday lives. The applications of optics can be seen everywhere. A list of more common examples of these applications include laser printers, fiber optic communication, internet switches, fiber optic telephone lines, compact disc players, credit cards bearing holograms, grocery checkout scanners, computers and eye surgery. The field of optics is an enabling technology and is growing at a rapid pace. Optical techniques are found in a wide range of areas such as surveying and construction, measurements of material parameters and deformation, flow measurements, communications, machine vision, laser cutting, drilling and welding, data storage, internet switches, optical computers and sensors etc. Surveys show that there is a growing demand for optical designers/scientists/ engineers every year. Opportunities for graduates in Optical", "lemma": "science light, once confine research lab science fiction novels, have find way everyday lives. application optic be see list more common example application include laser printers, fiber optic communication, internet switches, fiber optic telephone lines, compact disc players, credit card bear holograms, grocery checkout scanners, computer eye surgery. field optic be enable technology be grow rapid pace. Optical technique be find wide range area such surveying construction, measurement material parameter deformation, flow measurements, communications, machine laser cutting, drilling welding, data storage, internet switches, optical computer sensor etc. Surveys show be grow demand optical designers/scientists/ engineer year. Opportunities graduate Optical"}
{"source": "Eval/Optical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "is a growing demand for optical designers/scientists/ engineers every year. Opportunities for graduates in Optical Engineering are available in many industries, including automated inspection, consumer electronics, fiber optic communications, optical instrumentation, laser devices, radar systems, data storage etc.", "lemma": "be grow demand optical designers/scientists/ engineer year. Opportunities graduate Optical Engineering be available many industries, include automated inspection, consumer electronics, fiber optic communications, optical instrumentation, laser devices, radar systems, data storage etc."}
{"source": "Eval/Optical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "The Optical Engineering bachelor\u2019s degree program is one of the few in the country. This program provides a firm foundation for those interested in continuing thier studies in optics at the graduate level, as well as for those going into industry. The curriculum was developed by the faculty with input from industrial representatives as well as from renowned national and international optics educators. Because of the diverse applications of optics, the curriculum contains a mix of courses in physics and mathematics as well as humanities and social sciences. The Optical Engineering program at Rose-Hulman stresses laboratory instruction. We also encourage students to look at options for a double major, especially Optical Engineering with electrical, computer or mechanical engineering.\n\nStudents majoring in degree programs other than Optical Engineering are eligible to obtain an area minor in Optical Engineering.", "lemma": "Optical Engineering bachelor\u2019s degree program be few country. program provide firm foundation interested continue thier study optic graduate level, as well go curriculum be develop faculty input industrial representative as well renowned national international optic educators. diverse application curriculum contain mix course physic mathematics as well humanity social sciences. Optical Engineering program Rose-Hulman stress laboratory instruction. also encourage student look option double major, especially Optical Engineering electrical, computer mechanical engineering. Students major degree program other Optical Engineering be eligible obtain area minor Optical Engineering."}
{"source": "Eval/Optical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "The Department of Physics and Optical Engineering also offers an M.S. (Optical Engineering) degree. The masters level degree program complements the B.S. (Optical Engineering) degree program. Highly motivated students may obtain both a B.S. and an M.S. in Optical Engineering in a five-year period. A plan of study for this program must be approved by the end of the student\u2019s junior year.\n\nYou may view all information regarding Physics and Optical Engineering at our website: https://www.rose-hulman.edu/academics/academic-departments/physics-and-optical-engineering/index.html\n\nCurrent Students should visit the POE page under the Academics section of My Rose-Hulman for additional information.\n\nOE Program Educational Objectives", "lemma": "Department Physics Optical Engineering also offer M.S. (Optical Engineering) degree. master level degree program complement B.S. (Optical Engineering) degree program. Highly motivate student obtain B.S. M.S. {"source": "Eval/Optical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "We propose the creation of a new certificate program in Optical Communications to enhance the programs currently offered. Combining expertise in Optical and Electrical Engineering, this program requires an interdisciplinary emphasis that is beyond the traditional content of either of its parent programs. This program is more than just the creation of the certificate program Optical Communications. This program will be critical to help developing a more interdisciplinary interaction for students and faculty. The creation of a workgroup within the faculty of both departments will coordinate current courses and resources, create new courses of interest for the field, and develop a showcase testbed education and research laboratory. Primary objectives include the removal of redundancy from existing courses, increasing interaction between the PHOE and ECE Departments, and improving opportunities for students in the field.", "lemma": "propose creation new certificate program Optical Communications enhance program currently offered. Combining expertise Optical Electrical Engineering, program require interdisciplinary emphasis be traditional content parent programs. program be more just creation certificate program Optical Communications. program be critical help develop more interdisciplinary interaction student faculty. creation workgroup faculty department coordinate current course resources, create new course interest field, develop showcase testbed education research laboratory. Primary objective include removal redundancy exist courses, increase interaction PHOE ECE Departments, improve opportunity student field."}
{"source": "Eval/Optical%20Engineering.txt", "text": "This certificate is designed to give the student a firm theoretical and practical working knowledge in the area of fiber optic devices, optical communications, networks and its applications. The main purpose is to couch these fundamentals in a context that serves as the backbone for device, components and sub-system development for use in high-speed optical data and information links and networks. At the end of the program the student will be expected to:\n\nUnderstand the fundamental operation characteristics of high-speed optoelectronic components, such as laser transmitters, light modulators and receivers and passive fiber optic components as connectors, couplers, filters, and switches.\n\nUnderstand the technology and performance of analog and digital fiber optic links, optical amplification and optical wavelength division multiplexing and optical time division multiplexing networks.", "lemma": "certificate be design give student firm theoretical practical work knowledge area fiber optic devices, optical communications, network applications. main purpose be couch fundamental context serve backbone device, component sub-system development use high-speed optical data information link networks. end program student be expect to: Understand fundamental operation characteristic high-speed optoelectronic components, such laser transmitters, light modulators receiver passive fiber optic component connectors, couplers, filters, switches. Understand technology performance analog digital fiber optic links, optical amplification optical wavelength division multiplexing optical time division multiplexing networks."}

{"source": "Eval/civil-and-environmental-eng.txt", "text": "Civil Engineering\n\nThis program has been designed to build upon a student's undergraduate background and provide additional depth and breadth in the challenging and versatile profession of Civil Engineering. Subdiscipline focus in offered coursework is in structural engineering. In addition to courses in engineering, technical electives may be chosen from a variety offered in mathematics, physics, and chemistry.\n\nStudents interested in the areas of Environmental Engineering and Water Resources should refer to the Master of Science in Environmental Engineering\u00a0Program.\n\nDepartment emphasis is on the one-year course-based Master of Civil Engineering, summarized below. {"source": "Eval/civil-and-environmental-eng.txt", "text": "The objective of both programs, the Master of Civil Engineering and Master of Science in Civil Engineering, is to prepare graduates for early career advancement in the field of Civil Engineering by building upon their undergraduate training with advanced coursework and concentrated study of problems and topics relevant to the field.\n\nUpon completion of the Master in Civil Engineering and Master of Science in Civil Engineering, students will be able to\n\nEvaluate the results of a solution to a civil engineering problem.\n\nApply advanced concepts and principles to solve complex problems in a technical area appropriate to the practice of civil engineering.\n\nJustify appropriate problem approaches and techniques for complex problems in a technical area appropriate to the practice of civil engineering.\n\nDescribe or Demonstrate professional responsibilities relevant to the practice of civil engineering.\n\nFaculty and Staff Contacts\n\nMaster of Civil Engineering requirements\u00a0(course-based)", "lemma": "objective programs, Master Civil Engineering Master Science Civil Engineering, be prepare graduate early career advancement field Civil Engineering build undergraduate training advanced coursework concentrate study problem topic relevant field. {"source": "Eval/Biology.txt", "text": "Biology\n\nThe twenty-first century will see unparalleled advances in the biological sciences that will greatly impact the way we live. The areas of functional genomics and proteomics will drive discoveries in molecular medicine, gene therapy, and tissue engineering. Drug discovery will be facilitated by the elucidation of new target molecules and many pharmaceutical compounds will be produced using biological processes. Environmental management, remediation, and restoration will also advance as a result of new techniques and perspectives that emerge from the century of biology. Biologists will be at the forefront of the advances that will drive progress in medical, agricultural, environmental, and related industries.", "lemma": "twenty-first century see unparalleled advance biological science greatly impact way live. area functional genomics proteomics drive discovery molecular medicine, gene therapy, tissue engineering. {"source": "Eval/Biology.txt", "text": "Biochemistry & molecular biology is available to Rose-Hulman students as a second major. This means that the student will receive a first degree in some other discipline and then can augment their education with this program. Students whose first degree programs are in chemistry or chemical engineering will find the program easiest since there is considerable overlap between those programs and the biochemistry & molecular biology requirements. Students from other disciplines are also encouraged to participate, but will have to take more courses. All students are encouraged to take individual courses in the program, regardless of whether or not they wish to fulfill the second major requirements, or to participate in related research projects under faculty supervision.\n\nTwo degree or double major programs in Biochemistry & Molecular Biology and Biochemistry are not allowed.\n\nRequired Courses", "lemma": "Biochemistry molecular biology be available Rose-Hulman student second major. mean student receive first degree other discipline then augment education program. {"source": "Eval/engineering-management.txt", "text": "ENGINEERING MANAGEMENT\n\nThe engineering management master's program facilitates students' educational experiences to distinguish themselves from other engineers in the workplace. Through various instruction modes and experiences, students develop leadership and technical skills to positively address the human (behavioral) and technical opportunities presented in today's global work environment. The goal is to provide students with discipline-free managerial, leadership, and technical skills that accentuate their undergraduate STEM degrees and elevate their career trajectories.", "lemma": "ENGINEERING MANAGEMENT engineering management master's program facilitate students' educational experience distinguish other engineer workplace. various instruction mode experiences, student develop leadership technical skill positively address human (behavioral) technical opportunity present today's global work environment. goal be provide student discipline-free managerial, leadership, technical skill accentuate undergraduate STEM degree elevate career trajectories."}
{"source": "Eval/engineering-management.txt", "text": "The department offers two variations of the master's degree: Master of Science in Engineering Management (MSEM) and Master of Engineering Management (MEM).\u00a0 The MSEM degree requires a combination of coursework and a capstone project, while the MEM degree does not require a capstone project but instead requires eight (8) additional credit hours of graduate-level coursework. Both degree programs require three (3) one-credit hour EMGT graduate seminars, which expose students to relevant engineering management topics and experts that they would not be exposed to in other classes.\n\nWithin the course offerings of engineering management, students can explore the areas of entrepreneurship, operations, Six Sigma, and systems engineering as they relate to the discipline.", "lemma": "department offer variation master's degree: Master Science Engineering Management (MSEM) Master Engineering Management (MEM). MSEM degree require combination coursework capstone project, MEM degree do not require capstone project instead require (8) additional credit hour graduate-level coursework. Both degree program require (3) one-credit hour EMGT graduate seminars, expose student relevant engineering management topic expert not be expose other classes. course offering engineering management, student explore area entrepreneurship, operations, Six Sigma, system engineering relate discipline."}
{"source": "Eval/engineering-management.txt", "text": "Both degrees' objective is to prepare graduates for a diverse set of career opportunities in STEM fields or career advancement in their current field of study. We achieve these objectives by building upon their undergraduate training with advanced coursework and topics relevant to the engineering management discipline.\n\nMSEM and MEM Graduate Student Learning Outcomes\n\nStudent Outcomes are statements that describe what students are expected to have by the time of graduation.\n\nAcquire and apply knowledge or skills to demonstrate an understanding of political, economic, social, technical, environmental, or legal (PESTEL) issues relevant to engineering management.\n\nApply engineering or managerial knowledge to analyze organizational concerns or devise solutions utilizing appropriate qualitative or quantitative tools.\n\nMeet objectives or create value (for a project, process, or organization) through individual or collaborative effort.\n\nMaster of Science in Engineering Management (MSEM)", "lemma": "degrees' objective be prepare graduate diverse set career opportunity STEM field career advancement current field study. achieve objective build undergraduate training advanced coursework topic relevant engineering management discipline. {"source": "Eval/Civil%20Engineering.txt", "text": "Civil Engineering\n\nCivil engineering is a people-oriented profession that has long been in existence to serve the needs of mankind. It evolved as a formal discipline at the start of the 19th century with the advent of society\u2019s need for increased mobility and convenience. The role of the civil engineer has always been one that deals primarily with public works: the planning, design, and construction of airports, bridges, buildings, and transportation, irrigation, flood control, water supply and waste disposal systems. These civil engineering works not only manage our environment, but are part of the environment itself and, by their very nature, have important social and economic impacts.", "lemma": "Civil Engineering Civil engineering be people-oriented profession have long be existence serve need mankind. evolve formal discipline start 19th century advent society\u2019s need increase mobility convenience. role civil engineer have always be deal primarily public works: planning, design, construction airports, bridges, buildings, transportation, irrigation, flood control, water supply waste disposal systems. civil engineering work not only manage environment, be part environment and, very nature, have important social economic impacts."}
{"source": "Eval/Civil%20Engineering.txt", "text": "The civil engineering curriculum is designed to give the student a sound education in preparation for this role. The first two years include courses that deal with the principles of mathematics, physical and engineering sciences on which engineering concepts are based, as well as courses in humanities and social sciences and introductory courses in engineering and design. The last two years are devoted to developing the necessary technical competence, as well as the ability to apply the knowledge that the student has acquired to the design and synthesis of complex civil engineering projects. Project-based learning is an essential ingredient, and a year-long, client-based capstone design project highlights the senior year.", "lemma": "civil engineering curriculum be design give student sound education preparation role. first year include course deal principle mathematics, physical engineering science engineering concept be based, as well course humanity social science introductory course engineering design. last year be devote develop necessary technical competence, as well ability apply knowledge student have acquire design synthesis complex civil engineering projects. Project-based learning be essential ingredient, year-long, client-based capstone design project highlight senior year."}
{"source": "Eval/Civil%20Engineering.txt", "text": "The entire curriculum is oriented to develop a student\u2019s ability to think critically and logically. Upon graduation the student will be able to adapt this ability to the engineering environment of his or her choice. The curriculum in civil engineering will provide the student with the capacity for professional growth, either by advanced study or as a practicing professional engineer. A student may also use this academic background as a stepping stone to a position in management, administration, law, or some other non-engineering field.\n\nCivil Engineering Department's Mission Statement\n\nTo provide an excellent civil engineering education that prepares graduates to develop into professionals who will exceed the needs of their employers, clients, and community in a continually changing world.\n\nCivil Engineering Department\u2019s Program Educational Objectives and Student Learning Outcomes*\n\nProgram Educational Objectives", "lemma": "entire curriculum be orient develop student\u2019s ability think critically logically. {"source": "Eval/Civil%20Engineering.txt", "text": "Civil Engineering Department\u2019s Program Educational Objectives and Student Learning Outcomes*\n\nProgram Educational Objectives\n\nI. Graduates will demonstrate the ability to\u00a0perform\u00a0 essential engineering functions\u00a0in the design, management, or construction industry.\n\nII. Graduates will demonstrate the ability to\u00a0 design/construct complex engineering systems\u00a0in the broad-based engineering industry.\n\nIII. Graduates will demonstrate their\u00a0potential for\u00a0 technical leadership and management.\n\nStudent Learning Outcomes\n\nStudent Learning Outcomes\n\nMathematics: Apply mathematics, including differential equations and numerical methods, to solve engineering problems.\n\nScience: Apply principles of natural science to solve engineering problems.\n\nSocial Sciences and Humanities: Apply concepts and principles developed from humanities and social sciences to inform engineering design.\n\nMaterials Science: Apply concepts and principles of materials science to solve civil engineering problems.", "lemma": "Civil Engineering Department\u2019s Program Educational Objectives Student Learning Outcomes* Program Educational Objectives I. {"source": "Eval/Civil%20Engineering.txt", "text": "Materials Science: Apply concepts and principles of materials science to solve civil engineering problems.\n\nEngineering Mechanics: Apply concepts and principles of solid and fluid mechanics to solve engineering problems.\n\nExperimental Methods and Data Analysis: Develop and conduct civil engineering experiments in at least two technical areas, analyze and interpret experimental data, and use engineering judgement to draw conclusions.\n\nCritical Thinking and Problem Solving: Use critical thinking to formulate an effective solution to a civil engineering problem.\n\nProject Management: Apply concepts and principles of project management in the practice of civil engineering.\n\nEngineering Economics: Apply engineering economics concepts and principles to make engineering decisions.\n\nRisk and Uncertainty: Apply concepts and principles of probability and statistics to address uncertainty and risk relevant to civil engineering.", "lemma": "Materials Science: Apply concept principle material science solve civil engineering problems. Risk Uncertainty: Apply concept principle probability statistic address uncertainty risk relevant civil engineering."}
{"source": "Eval/Civil%20Engineering.txt", "text": "Breadth in Civil Engineering Areas: Apply concepts and principles to solve problems in at least four technical areas appropriate to civil engineering.\n\nDesign: Apply an engineering design process to complex engineering problems in more than one civil engineering technical area.\n\nTechnical Depth: Apply advanced concepts and principles to solve engineering problems.\n\nSustainability: Apply principles of sustainability in the solution of civil engineering problems.\n\nCommunication: Prepare and present technical content to both specialized and general audiences in an effective manner within verbal, written, and graphical formats.\n\nLeadership: Apply leadership concepts and principles to direct the efforts of a small group. (Affective)\n\nTeamwork: Function effectively as a member of a team. {"source": "Eval/Early Alert Reporting RHIT.txt", "text": "Behavioral, Emotional, or Mental Health Concerns\nIf you have a\u00a0behavioral,\u00a0emotional, or\u00a0mental\u00a0health\u00a0concern about a student, please submit a Rose Cares Report or contact\u00a0Kyle Rhodes.\nWhile not an exhaustive list, behaviors you should report include:\nAnger problems\nPreoccupation with violence and/or weapons\nRepeated non-compliance\nStrange, atypical, and aberrant behaviors\nParanoia\nActing out\nDepression\nAssignments that focus on threatening behaviors (to themselves or others)\nUse of drugs and/or alcohol\nSuicidal ideation\nOther behaviors uncharacteristic of an individual's typical behavior\nEven if the behavior seems minor at the time, please submit a \nreport.\u00a0\u00a0We will connect information provided by other", "lemma": "Behavioral, Emotional, Mental Health Concerns have behavioral, emotional, mental health concern student, please submit Rose Cares Report contact Kyle Rhodes. not exhaustive list, behavior report include: Anger problem Preoccupation violence and/or weapon Repeated non-compliance Strange, atypical, aberrant behavior Paranoia Acting out Depression Assignments focus threaten behavior (to others) Use drug and/or alcohol Suicidal ideation Other behavior uncharacteristic individual's typical behavior Even behavior seem minor time, please submit report. connect information provide other"}

{"source": "Eval/Student-Handbook23.txt", "text": "pg. 24 Smoking in the Residence Halls  \nThe Institute is dedicated to providing a healthy, comfortable, and productive \nenvironment for all students, faculty, staff and guests. The Institute recognizes the \nhealth hazards associated with using smokeless and smoking tobacco products and \nthe adverse effects of exposure to second hand smoke by non -smokers.  \nEffective July 1, 2017, Rose -Hulman Institute of Technology is a tobacco and \nsmoke -free campus. This policy applies to all faculty, staff, students, visitors and \nvendors.  Smoking and/or tobacco use is prohibited on Rose -Hulman property and \nall vehicles parked or operated on camp us property as well as the Circle K gas \nstation at the southeast entrance to campus.", "lemma": "pg. Smoking Residence Halls Institute be dedicate provide healthy, comfortable, productive environment students, faculty, staff guests. Institute recognize health hazard associate use smokeless smoking tobacco product adverse effect exposure second hand smoke non -smokers. Effective July Rose -Hulman Institute Technology be tobacco smoke -free campus. policy apply faculty, staff, students, visitor vendors. Smoking and/or tobacco use be prohibit Rose -Hulman property vehicle park operate camp property as well Circle K gas station southeast entrance campus."}

It also includes any \nproduct intended to mimic tobacco products, contain tobacco flavoring, or deliver nicotine other than for the purpose of cessation.  \nVisitation Policy  \nA. Freshman Residence Halls -  Fall Quarter \nVisitation by individuals who do not live on the floor shall be permissible in student rooms of the freshman residence halls between the hours of 8 a.m. to 12 a .m. \nSunday through Thursday and 8 a.m. to 2 a.m. Friday and Saturday during the Fall Quarter, provided that each resident is personally responsible for a proper atmosphere prevailing in the visitation area during visitation hours . Failure to abide \nby the above rules or other res hall policies could mean loss of visitation privileges for the person or persons involved.
